results.title: Memories of a radio
results.creator_credit: Gordon Preston and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Gordon Preston talks about his life, his love of the radio and the comfort it brings him. He shares key experiences from his life, like when he first arrived in Melbourne by ship and his vivid dreams and how his radio has followed him everywhere, sometimes illuminating the life he is missing out on, sometimes illuminating his memories and dreams.
results.description: Gordon Preston talks about his life, his love of the radio and the comfort it brings him. He shares key experiences from his life, like when he first arrived in Melbourne by ship and his vivid dreams and how his radio has followed him everywhere, sometimes illuminating the life he is missing out on, sometimes illuminating his memories and dreams.

results.creator_credit: Kylie O'Brien and ACMI Digital Storytelling

results.title: How I see it on the street
results.creator_credit: Robbie Williams and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: The way I see it, there are a lot of bums in the world. Stories from a Big Issue vendor who operates from a wheelchair, about the variety of bums in the world and how they behave towards him.

results.title: Homage to the herbster
results.creator_credit: Leo Kane and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Sometimes he inscribes his name in wet cement. As long as he spells it correctly, I’ll let it ride. A simple tale of an intense relationship between a Big Issue vendor and his terrier, his partner in both work and life.
results.description: Sometimes he inscribes his name in wet cement. As long as he spells it correctly, I’ll let it ride. A simple tale of an intense relationship between a Big Issue vendor and his terrier, his partner in both work and life.

results.title: Dear mother
results.creator_credit: Judith Mahfoud and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Life wasn’t meant to be easy, but it still can be profoundly beautiful. Judith delves into the childhood of her mother, to try to understand her better so she can pass this knowledge to her five sons and to honour the life of her mother, who grew up feeling like she was nobody’s child.
results.description: Life wasn’t meant to be easy, but it still can be profoundly beautiful. Judith delves into the childhood of her mother, to try to understand her better so she can pass this knowledge to her five sons and to honour the life of her mother, who grew up feeling like she was nobody’s child.

results.title: Geelong TCUFA : weaving and winding : more than a job : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Five employees of carpet manufacturer Brintons and Textile Clothing and Footwear Union tell about their lives before, during and after working at Brintons. The factory closed in June 2008, leaving 100 people without jobs.

results.title: Why did you leave such a beautiful place?
results.creator_credit: Margaret O'Connell and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Margaret O’Connell tells of how she moved to be with her sister in Geelong, of her first days at Brintons carpet factory and how her loneliness was soon replaced by the family she made there. She join the Equal Opportunity and Consultative Committees and, when the factory closed in 2008, had been there for 32 years.
results.title_for_label: Why did you leave such a beautiful place?

She join the Equal Opportunity and Consultative Committees and, when the factory closed in 2008, had been there for 32 years.

results.title: The Loom never stops : a conversation with Thomas Ladgrove
results.creator_credit: Thomas Ladgrove and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: When Thomas Ladgrove started work at Brintons carpet factory in 1967, he was a ward of the state. He eventually started working with the loom and became the youngest weaver in Australia and England at age 18. He describes his work on the loom as well as staff morale when it became clear that Brintons was suffering, the subsequent rumours and worry and then the closure when the announcement to cease operations was made.
results.title_for_label: The Loom never stops : a conversation with Thomas Ladgrove

results.title: Long term employment
results.creator_credit: Michael Farquhar and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Michael Farquhar walked into Brintons to leave his details at reception. The same day he had and interview and got a job. In his time there, he moved through many different areas and went through many life changes, from renting an appartment to marriage, owning a home and raising a family. When Brintons closed in 2008, Michael had worked there for 21 years. He talks about what it was like to work there, in the good and bad times.
results.description: Michael Farquhar walked into Brintons to leave his details at reception. The same day he had and interview and got a job. In his time there, he moved through many different areas and went through many life changes, from renting an appartment to marriage, owning a home and raising a family. When Brintons closed in 2008, Michael had worked there for 21 years. He talks about what it was like to work there, in the good and bad times.

results.title: The Journey begins at midnight
results.creator_credit: Joseph Jovic and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Josip tells of his upbringing on a farm in Coatia and how the lure of a better life brought him to Australia, Geelong and, eventually, to Brintons Carpets. Learning English within a few years, Josip soon became a shop steward and a representative on the Consultative Committee and he tells of the closure of Brintons and how it led to his retirement.
